Not sure I understand the problem. Is the function failing?

On Thu, Apr 20, 2017 at 6:52 AM, Androbin ***@***.***> wrote: @ebrevdo <https://github.com/ebrevdo> I have tried a few variations for num_frames: num_frames = tf.cast(48.0, tf.int32) at least results in a proper value. Any modification to that seems to break it, including: num_frames = 1 + tf.cast(48.0, tf.int32) num_frames = tf.cast(tf.ceil(48.0), tf.int32) — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. body_text:
Not sure I understand the problem.  Is the function failing?
…
On Thu, Apr 20, 2017 at 6:52 AM, Androbin ***@***.***> wrote:
 @ebrevdo <https://github.com/ebrevdo>
 I have tried a few variations for num_frames:
 num_frames = tf.cast(48.0, tf.int32)
 at least results in a proper value.
 Any modification to that seems to break it, including:
 num_frames = 1 + tf.cast(48.0, tf.int32)
 num_frames = tf.cast(tf.ceil(48.0), tf.int32)

 —

body:
Not sure I understand the problem.  Is the function failing?

On Thu, Apr 20, 2017 at 6:52 AM, Androbin <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @ebrevdo <https://github.com/ebrevdo>
> I have tried a few variations for num_frames:
> num_frames = tf.cast(48.0, tf.int32)
> at least results in a proper value.
> Any modification to that seems to break it, including:
> num_frames = 1 + tf.cast(48.0, tf.int32)
> num_frames = tf.cast(tf.ceil(48.0), tf.int32)
>
